1. A 3-month-old female infant was brought to the pediatric neurology clinic due to exaggerated startle responses and frequent episodes of stiffness since birth. Her parents reported that sudden loud noises or unexpected touches cause her to have a generalized stiffening and brief apnea, sometimes leading to cyanosis. Developmental milestones were otherwise normal, but the exaggerated startle interfered with feeding and sleep. Physical examination revealed marked hypertonia and persistent Moro reflex beyond the neonatal period. There was no family history of seizures or neuromuscular disorders, although her maternal uncle had a history of sudden infant death syndrome. EEG showed no epileptiform activity, and metabolic workup was unremarkable. Genetic testing identified a pathogenic mutation in the GLRA1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of hyperekplexia type 1. She was started on low-dose clonazepam, which significantly reduced the frequency and severity of her startle episodes.

ANSWER: I'm here 'cause my baby girl, she's been really bumping into things and stiffening up a lot ever since she was born. Sometimes she stops breathing for a bit when she gets startled really loud or when she's touched unexpectedly. It's been making it harder to feed her and she doesn't sleep well either.
